revision.comment: /* External links */re-categorisation per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 September 19]], possibly with general fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{redirect|Daniel Choi|the Korean actor|Choi Daniel}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox military person |image=Dan Choi at Bryant Park NYC.JPG |caption=Dan Choi at a [[LGBT pride]] rally in [[Bryant Park]] |name=Daniel Choi |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1981|2|22|}} |birth_place= |nickname= |allegiance= United States |branch=[[United States Army]] |serviceyears=1999–2010<ref name=osborne/> |rank=[[File:US-O2 insignia.svg|10px]] [[First Lieutenant#United States|First Lieutenant]] |commands= |unit= |battles=[[Operation Iraqi Freedom]] |awards= |laterwork= }}
'''Daniel Choi''' (born February 22, 1981)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bentalaska.com/2011/10/dan-choi-soldier-activist |title=Dan Choi, soldier & activist (LGBT History Month) |publisher=Bent Alaska |date= 8 October 2011 |accessdate=2013-11-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414154517/http://www.bentalaska.com/2011/10/dan-choi-soldier-activist/|archivedate=April 14, 2012}}</ref> is an American former infantry officer in the [[United States Army]] who served in combat in the [[Iraq war]] during 2006-2007.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/us/12military.html | work=The New York Times | title=Gay Guardsman Has Returned to Drills With His Unit | first=Elisabeth | last=Bumiller | date=February 12, 2010 | accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref> He became an [[LGBT rights]] [[activism|activist]] following his [[coming out]] on ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]'' in March 2009 and publicly challenged America's [[Don't Ask, Don't Tell]] policy, which forbade [[lesbian]], [[gay]] and [[Bisexuality|bisexual]] ([[LGBT|LGB]]) service members from serving [[coming out|openly]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/05/07/dan-choi-fired-gay-arabic_n_199592.html |title=Dan Choi, Fired Gay Arabic-Speaking Linguist, Speaks To Rachel Maddow|format=Flash video|publisher=Huffington Post|date=May 7, 2009|first=Marcus|last=Baram}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29836340/|title='The Rachel Maddow Show' for Friday March 20, 2009|format=Transcript|publisher=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref>
On October 19, 2010, Choi applied to rejoin the US Army.<ref name="Salon">{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Pareene |title="Don't ask, don't tell" no longer enforced, Dan Choi reenlists |publisher=Salon |date=October 20, 2010 |url=http://www.salon.com/news/dont_ask_dont_tell/?story=/politics/war_room/2010/10/20/dadt_choi_appeal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=October 29, 2010 |first=Anne|last=Flaherty|first2=Julie|last2=Watson| title=Troops discharged for being gay try to re-enlist |publisher=[[WTVM]].com |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|url=http://www.wtvm.com/Global/story.asp?S=13348529 }}</ref>
==Early life== Choi is a native of [[Orange County, California|Orange County]], [[California]], the son of a [[Korean American|Korean-American]] [[Baptist]] [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]].<ref>{{cite news | last= Crary | first= David | title=Gay West Point grads target ban on serving openly |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2009/04/12/national/a102259D00.DTL | date=April 12, 2009 | work=San Francisco Chronicle| archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5oM3eygbY |archivedate=2010-03-19| accessdate=2010-07-22}}</ref> He graduated from [[Tustin High School]] then attended the [[United States Military Academy|United States Military Academy at West Point]].<ref name="OCRegister">{{cite web| title = Gay soldier's discharge delivered to parents' Tustin home | publisher = The Orange County Register |author=James, Elysse |date=July 23, 2010 | url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/choi-259042-don-military.html | accessdate=2010-07-23}}</ref>
Choi was very active with extracurriculars during his high school years. He served as student body president, was on the varsity swim team, and was the marching band drum major. During his senior year, after watching ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'', he decided to attend West Point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iamkoream.com/outspoken/ |title=Outspoken « KoreAm Journal – Korean America's Premier Magazine |publisher=Iamkoream.com |date=2010-07-23 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>
==Military education and career== [[File:Dan Choi West Point.jpg|thumb|left|Cadet Choi on his West Point graduation portrait, 2003]] Choi graduated from [[United States Military Academy|West Point]] in 2003 with degrees in [[Arabic]] and [[environmental engineering]].<ref name="ArmyTimes">{{cite web | title = West Point grads form gay support group | publisher = Army Times |author=McMichael, William |date=March 18, 2009 | url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/03/military_westpoint_knightsout_031609w/ | accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> Choi served as an infantry officer in [[Iraq]] with the [[10th Mountain Division]]<ref name="ArmyTimes"/> in 2006 and 2007. In June 2008, he transferred from active duty Army to the [[New York Army National Guard]]. Choi served as an Army guardsman with the 1st Battalion, [[69th Infantry Regiment (United States)|69th Infantry]], based in Manhattan.<ref name="ArmyTimes"/>
Choi received a discharge letter following his coming out on ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]''. In response, Choi penned an [[open letter]] to [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] and the [[United States Congress]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=7569476&page=1|author=Choi, Daniel| title=Lt. Daniel Choi Begs to Keep His Job in National Guard|date=May 11, 2009|work=Open Letter to President Obama and Every Member of Congress|publisher=[[ABC News]]}}</ref> In the letter, Choi challenged the morality and wisdom of Don't Ask, Don't Tell, writing that the policy is "a slap in the face to me. It is a slap in the face to my soldiers, peers and leaders who have demonstrated that an infantry unit can be professional enough to accept diversity, to accept capable leaders, to accept skilled soldiers."
Despite his appeal and a [[Courage Campaign]] petition signed by almost 162,000 people,<ref>[http://www.couragecampaign.org/page/s/SupportDanSign the Statement of Support for Lt. Dan Choi]. [[Courage Campaign]].</ref> on June 30, 2009, a panel of New York National Guard officers recommended that Choi be discharged from the military.<ref>[http://cnnwire.blogs.cnn.com/2009/06/30/discharge-recommended-for-gay-army-officer-supporters-say/ Discharge recommended for gay Army officer, supporters say]. CNN. June 30, 2009.</ref> As of February 2010, Choi was serving again in his Army National Guard unit, the discharge having not yet been "finalized".<ref>Montopoli, Brian (February 9, 2010).[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-6191549-503544.html Openly Gay Soldier Dan Choi Back in Uniform]. [[CBS News]] blog.</ref> On June 29, 2010, Choi's discharge was finalized.<ref name = osborne>{{cite web|last=Osborne|first=Duncan|title=Dan Choi, Now Discharged, Sees DC Protest Charge Dismissed|publisher=''[[Gay City News]]''|date=July 20, 2010|url=http://www.gaycitynews.com/articles/2010/07/20/gay_city_news/news/doc4c465ff7a178c126438367.txt|accessdate=July 21, 2010}}</ref>
Choi is among 59 gay Arabic linguists, along with nine gay [[Persian language|Farsi]] linguists, who have faced a discharge from the U.S. military from 2004 through 2009, according to the [[Servicemembers Legal Defense Network]].<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/29/gay-veteran-us-army-choi | title=Don't ask, don't tell: gay veteran of Iraq takes on US army |last=Nasaw | first=Daniel | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | location = London | accessdate=November 6, 2009 | date=June 29, 2009}}</ref>
==Gay rights activism== [[File:KoreAm 2009-08 Cover.jpg|thumb|left|On the cover of ''[[KoreAm]]'', August 2009]] Since Choi's coming out, 38 West Point alumni also came out and announced the formation of [[Knights Out]], an organization of West Point alumni who support the rights of LGBT soldiers to serve openly. Choi was one of the founding members and is the spokesperson for the group.<ref name="KnightsOut">{{cite web|publisher=Knights Out|title=West Point Alumni supporting the LGBT soldiers|work=Home page|url=http://knightsout.org/|accessdate=2009-10-11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091130222859/http://www.knightsout.org/|archivedate=November 30, 2009}}</ref> The organization offers "to help their alma mater educate future Army leaders on the need to accept and honor the sacrifices of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender troops."<ref name="KnightsOut"/><ref name="KOmission-Advocate">{{cite web|title=West Point Grads Form Gay Support Group |last=Dizon|first=Rhiza|date=March 17, 2009|publisher=Advocate|url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2009/03/17/West_Point_Grads_Come_Out,_Form_Support_Group/|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>
Choi has also spoken at numerous gay rights events, including a march in Los Angeles following the [[Supreme Court of California|California Supreme Court]]'s affirmation of [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]]. On May 27, 2009, he addressed a demonstration of gay activists outside the [[Beverly Hilton Hotel]], where President [[Barack Obama]] was speaking at a [[Democratic National Committee]] fund raising event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lieutenant Dan Choi Takes 'Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell' Directly To Obama| author=Milazzo, Linda|url=http://www.laprogressive.com/2009/05/30/dan-choi-takes-dont-ask-dont-tell-to-obama/|publisher=L.A. Progressive|date=May 30, 2009}}</ref> In addition, Choi spoke at the 2009 [[Gay and Lesbian Pride Month|Pride Rally]] in [[New York City]] and served as a Grand Marshal alongside Knights Out in San Francisco's 2009 [[San Francisco Pride|Gay Pride Parade]].<ref>{{cite web|title =Gay Pride Grand Marshal Lt. Dan Choi Faces Discharge |author=Keeling, Brock| publisher=SFist |date=June 30, 2009| url=http://sfist.com/2009/06/30/gay_pride_grand_marshal_lt_dan_choi.php |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>
On July 16, 2009, Choi was in [[Culver City, California]], to introduce the premiere of Abe Forman-Greenwald's documentary called ''Silent Partners''.<ref name="LATimes">{{cite news|title='Silent partner' examines what happens when people 'don't tell'|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-gay-military18-2009jul18,0,848628.story|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 18, 2009|first=Alexandra|last=Zavis}}</ref> The documentary is the fourth episode in the ''[[In Their Boots]]'' series, with the episode focusing on the partners of [[LGBT]] soldiers deployed to Iraq and [[Afghanistan]]. In the episode, Choi criticizes the U.S. military's neglect of the partners of service members.<ref name="LATimes"/>
In February 2010 Choi was selected to be a Grand Marshal of the 41st Annual New York [[Pride parade|LGBT Pride March]] by its producers, [[Heritage of Pride]].<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=Heritage of Pride, Inc. |work=NYC Pride |date=February 9, 2010|title=Lieutenant Dan Choi to serve as Grand Marshal |url=http://www.nycpride.org/pressrelease/DC_PressRelease.pdf| format=PDF|accessdate=2010-07-22}}</ref><ref name="lezgetReal02">{{cite news|title='Lt. Dan Choi to be Grand Marshal at Pride Parade|url=http://www.lezgetreal.com/?p=26326|publisher=LEZGET Real|date=February 10, 2010|first=Natasia|last=Langfelder}}</ref><ref name="advoc022010">{{cite news|title='Gay N.Y. Hearts Dan Choi|url=http://www.advocate.com/news/daily-news/2010/02/10/gay-ny-hearts-dan-choi|publisher=[[The Advocate]]|date=February 10, 2010|first=Neal|last=Broverman}}</ref> At the event, Choi led the Pledge of Allegiance at the New York City Council Chambers.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Lombardi, Frank |author2=Lisberg, Adam|publisher=[[New York Daily News]] |date=June 15, 2010|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/06/15/2010-06-15_dan_choi_gay_iraq_war_veteran_is_honored_last_night_annual_gay_pride_celebration.html|title=Dan Choi, Iraq war veteran, is honored at annual gay pride celebration}}</ref>
In March 2013, [[Outright Libertarians]] announced that Dan Choi was joining the GLBTQ caucus of the [[Libertarian Party of the United States|Libertarian Party]] as an honorary board member.<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=Outright Libertarians, Inc. |work=Mike Shipley |date=March 19, 2013|title=Dan Cho Joins Outright |url=http://www.outrightusa.org/joomla25/blog/241-press-release-dan-choi-joins-outright|accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
In June 2013, Choi and numerous other celebrities appeared in a video showing support for [[Chelsea Manning]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/celebrity-bradley-manning-video-93041.html#ixzz2WgfpNmys |title=Celeb video: ‘I am Bradley Manning’ - Patrick Gavin |publisher=Politico.Com |date=2013-06-20 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=UFFkcCh-pCc |title=I am Bradley Manning (full HD) |publisher=YouTube |date=2013-06-18 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>
===2010 protests and arrests=== On March 18, 2010, Choi and another ousted military officer, Capt. Jim Pietrangelo, handcuffed themselves to the fence of the [[White House]]. They were eventually removed with the use of a [[Master keying|master]] handcuff key and arrested.<ref name="HuffingtonPost">{{cite news|title='Dan Choi Handcuffs Himself to White House In Don't Ask Don't Tell Protest'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/18/dan-choi-handcuffs-himsel_n_504439.html|publisher=Huffington Post|date=March 18, 2010|first=Nick|last=Graham}}</ref><ref>Conant, Eve (March 18, 2010).[http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/thehumancondition/archive/2010/03/18/Lt.-Dan-Choi-Arrested-at-White-House-More-Civil-Disobedience-Expected-In-Protest-of-Don-t-Ask-Don-t-Tell-.aspxLt. Dan Choi Arrested at White House]. [[Newsweek]].com</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Lt. Dan Choi Arrested at White House During Gay Rights Rally|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20000740-503544.html|publisher=[[CBS]]|date=March 18, 2010|first=Brian|last=Montopoli}}</ref> Choi and Pietrangelo were initially set to be tried for "failure to obey a lawful order" on April 26, 2010.<ref>Najafi, Yusef (March 19, 2010). [http://www.metroweekly.com/news/?ak=5006 "Not Guilty, Not Ashamed and Not Finished"]. [[Metro Weekly]].</ref><ref>Conant, Eve (March 22, 2010). [http://www.newsweek.com/id/235290 "Lt. Dan Choi on His Arrest Over DADT"]. [[Newsweek]].com.</ref> Trial was postponed until July 14, at which time the charges against both men were dropped.<ref name = osborne />
On April 20, 2010, Choi and Pietrangelo again participated in a self-chaining protest on the White House fence with Petty Officer Larry Whitt, Petty Officer (Rtd.) [[Autumn Sandeen]], Cadet Mara Boyd and Cpl. Evelyn Thomas. All six were removed with a master hand-cuff key and arrested.<ref>{{Cite news|title='Dan Choi, Other Gay Rights Protesters Arrested After Chaining Selves to White House Fence'|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20002942-503544.html|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=April 20, 2010|first=Brian|last=Montopoli}}</ref>
On May 27, 2010, Choi and Pietrangelo began a [[hunger strike]] until President Obama ends DADT and adds a non-discrimination policy to the [[Code of the U.S. Fighting Force|military code]].<ref>Conant, Eve (May 28, 2010).[http://www.newsweek.com/blogs/the-gaggle/2010/05/28/hunger-strike-begins-after-congress-votes-on-don-t-ask-don-t-tell-repeal-amendment-.html "House Approves Repeal of 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'"]. [[Newsweek]].com.</ref> They ended the hunger strike seven days later, with Choi saying, "The fast of the past seven days has been a success because people have been educated to the use of fasting as a tool to bring attention to a set of clear political and social demands."<ref>[http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2010/06/02/Choi_Ends_DADT_Hunger_Strike/ "Choi Ends DADT Hunger Strike"]. [[The Advocate]], June 2, 2010.</ref>
In November, 2010, Choi again handcuffed himself to the White House fence with 12 other protestors. He was subsequently arrested and charged in Federal court. The case of [[United States v. Choi]] took more than two years to conclude. On March 28, 2013, Choi was convicted of a misdemeanor charge of "Failure to Obey Lawful Order" and fined $100.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dan Choi Trial Over 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' White House Protest Put On Hold |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/01/dan-choi-trial_n_944629.html |work=Huff Post - Politics |publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc. |accessdate=6 February 2012 |author=JESSICA GRESKO |date=1 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Anya|first=Callahan|title=Why Gay Military Activist Lt. Dan Choi Won’t Be Paying His $100 Court Fine|url=http://campusprogress.org/articles/why_gay_military_activist_lt._dan_choi_wont_be_paying_his_100_court_fine/|publisher=Campus Progress|quote=After more than two years of legal battles, LGBT activist Lt. Dan Choi was convicted of a misdemeanor by a federal judge and fined $100 on Thursday, March 28. Lt. Choi was tried for one count of "Failure to Obey Lawful Order" for a protesting Don’t Ask Don’t Tell (DADT) in front of the White House back in 2010. Since the judge ruled in the case, Lt. Choi has stated publicly that he won't pay the $100 fee on moral principle and free-speech grounds.}}</ref>
=== Court ruling === [[File:Marriage Equality in New York- Interview with Lt. Dan Choi.webm|thumb|right|250px|Dan Choi being interviewed in New York City, July 2011.]] On October 12, 2010, U.S. federal judge [[Virginia Phillips]] ordered the Department of Defense to stop enforcing “don’t ask, don’t tell” –the law that prohibits openly gay people from serving in the military.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2010/1012/Pentagon-must-stop-don-t-ask-don-t-tell-federal-judge-rules/ "Pentagon must stop don't ask don't tell, federal judge rules"]. [[Christian Science Monitor]]. October 12, 2010.</ref> On October 19, Judge Phillips further refused a federal government request to stay the order pending appeal.<ref name="CSM19">[http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2010/1019/No-delay-for-don-t-ask-don-t-tell-ruling-so-Pentagon-takes-gays-for-now/ "No delay for 'don't ask don't tell' ruling, so Pentagon takes gays for now"]. Christian Science Monitor. October 19, 2010.</ref> That same day, Dan Choi went to the Times Square recruiting station in New York to rejoin the U.S. Army<ref name="CSM19"/> (referred to in one source as "reaccesion");<ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2278627/ "Don't Ask, Don't Tell, Don't Come Back?"]. Slate.com. December 19, 2010.</ref> his request is in process.<ref name="Salon"/> Choi reaffirmed his intention to rejoin the service on December 19.<ref name="NYM2">[http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/12/dan_choi.html "Dan Choi Intends to Rejoin the Military"] [[New York Magazine]], December 22, 2010.</ref> Following the repeal of "don't ask, don't tell" by Congress, Choi was present at the [[U.S. Interior Department]] to attend President Obama's signing of the bill on December 22, 2010.<ref name="AJC">[http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/obama-signs-dont-ask-785188.html "Obama signs 'don't ask, don't tell' repeal"] [[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] (AP), December 22, 2010. (Photo captions).</ref>
=== 2011 arrest in Moscow === On May 28, 2011, Choi was among a number of both Russian and foreign activists (including [[Louis-Georges Tin]] and [[Andy Thayer]]) who were arrested by Moscow police when [[Moscow Pride]] was held in spite of a ban by city authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.ukgaynews.org.uk/Archive/11/May/Moscow%20Gay%20Pride%20Blog.htm|title = Moscow Gay Pride - Our Annual Blog|publisher = UK Gay News|date = May 28, 2011}}</ref>
==See also== {{wikiquote}} * ''[[United States v. Choi]]'' * [[Sexual orientation and the United States military]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Daniel Choi}} *[http://www.democracynow.org/2009/10/13/love_is_worth_it_iraq_war "Iraq War Vet Facing Discharge Helps Lead Massive Rally for Gay Rights"](Video, transcript). Choi appearance. ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' October 13, 2009. *[http://www.democracynow.org/2010/8/4/i_have_no_regret_to_anybody "I Have No Regret to Anybody in the Military."] (Video, transcript). Choi appearance, interview. ''Democracy Now!'' August 4, 2010 *[http://themoth.org/posts/stories/made-to-be-broken "Made To Be Broken" audio of Daniel Choi giving a talk for [[The Moth]]] <!-- already in, just above here -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Choi, Dan}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:American people of Korean descent]] [[Category:American LGBT military personnel]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Iraq War]] [[Category:American military personnel discharged for homosexuality]] [[Category:American military personnel of Korean descent]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Baptists from the United States]] <!--Religious and LGBT categories may not be included unless the person publicly self-identifies with the label in question and it is relevant to their public lives[[Category:Korean Baptists]] [[Category:LGBT Christians]]--> [[Category:People from Orange County, California]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT scientists]] [[Category:LGBT scientists from the United States]] [[Category:American linguists]] [[Category:Arabists]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:LGBT American people of Asian descent]]
